responses: Hi there, how can I help?

patterns: How many subjects do I need to enter the department?
responses: 5 CSEC subjects(grades 1-3), or equivalent(must include Engliash, Math and at least 2 science subjects) plus a science subject at the advance level-CAPE(both units at grades 1-5) or a Teacher's College Diploma or Associate Degree in Math,Science or Infomation Technology
The Department is committed to delivering high quility taught programmes that prepare students to compete in a global marketplace

The programmes offered have been set out in the IEEE/ACM guides for computing curricula.Our students are therefore assured that course contents are aligned with international standards.The high performance of our graduates in the workplace serves as a proven track record.
The range of assesment methods and techniques employed, enable students to demonstrate the depth of their understanding and their capacity for independent thought.

what programmes do the department offer?
responses: We offer Bachelor of Science Degrees in Computer Science,Computer Studies, Information Technology, Software Engineering, Computer Systems Engineering

patterns: what careers can I get with a computing degree?
what jobs can I get with a computing degree?
what can i become with a computer science degree?
responses: Careers are not limited to: Software Engineer/Developer, Database Admin,Entrepreneur,Multimedia Specialist, Network Admin, Researcher/Teacher/Lecturer, Computer Analyst, Web Master/Admin,Information Tech Project Manager, Technical Writer, Computer Systems Engineer

This course is intended to lay the foundations for developing good problem solving skills within students of Computing. As a consequence, no knowledge of programming is assumed as a prerequisite to this course, yet at the end of the course students would have been exposed in a concrete way to computation, and the tools that have been developed to control its complexity as well as implement its processes in physical devices.This course therefore serves as one of the cornerstone courses of the entire curriculum for the Information Technology programme and the Computer Science major, and requires only that students come to it prepared to think in ways unfamiliar to them.

patterns: what do i have to do before comp1126?
what courses are required to do comp1126?
what are the prerequisites for comp1126?
responses: A CAPE (Units 1 and 2 {or A-level}) Science subject, ECON1003, Teacher’s College Diploma, Associate Degree in Mathematics or Science OR Information Technology

patterns: Which semester should I do comp1126 in?
How many credits does comp1126 has?

responses: The course will last for the first six weeks in the semester.

The primary goal of the course is to introduce students to the big ideas in Computer Science, and how they are used to control the complexity of developing large computational systems. In this course, recognising patterns of problem solving is more important than the efficiency of the solutions themselves. An interpreted language is used to facilitate rapid feedback to the student as she experiments with proposed solutions to a problem. We hope that this mode of interaction will build confidence in students as they learn the joys and challenges of programming. This course continues the entry level course COMP1126. It covers concepts and tools that are essential in strengthening the learning of programming. These include data structures and higher order functions.
